events.name: Become a GIVE Circle Facilitator!
events.description:
Become a Growing through Inclusive Vulnerability and Empathy (GIVE) Circle Facilitator in this two-part training!

GIVE Circles are opportunities for participants, whether students, faculty or staff, to engage in deep listening and conversation of shared experiences related to various topics. They are moments to build connections, understanding and empathy amongst those participating. GIVE Circles can play an important role in bringing the campus community together to explore our common humanity. 

As a Facilitator, you would be an important part of creating and maintaining spaces on campus for students, faculty, and staff to establish self-agency and cultivate a sense of belonging.

Here are the expectations to maintain active facilitator status:

Shadowing/Observation: You'll be provided with the opportunity to shadow/observe a GIVE Circle if you don't feel 100% comfortable after the training. 

Facilitation: To sustain facilitators, we ask them to facilitate circles in their areas and embed in their initiatives (don't worry, we'll address this in the training). 

Upon completing facilitator training: host and facilitate two (2) circles per academic year

Returning facilitators: host and facilitate two (2) circles per semester (this will begin 2026-27 academic year).

Check-In: participate in at least one (1) facilitator check-in per semester to share experiences with the SJE team to receive continued guidance and support.

Ongoing Development: Complete one (1) professional development opportunity per semester offered through SJE. 

Reflections: Submit a short reflection (1/2 page) after each facilitated session. 

Itâ€™s important that you attend the entirety of the training to be capable of facilitating GIVE Circles in your areas. 

Part one: Tuesday, December 9, 1pm-3pm, Founders Memorial Library, Room 202

Part two: Thursday, December 11, 1pm-3pm, Founders Memorial Library, Room 202

 

You can register for the two-day training here. 

The deadline to register is Monday, December 8.

events.name: Exhibition: "How We Rebuild"
events.description:
After conflicts have ended, what does it take to recover the heartbeat of humanity? This penetrating and transformative photography exhibition draws from 12 years of work created by grant winners and finalists from The Aftermath Project, a nonprofit organization committed to telling the other half of war stories, after the conflicts have ended â€” what it takes for individuals to rebuild destroyed lives and homes, to restore civil societies and to address the lingering wounds of war while struggling to create new avenues for peace. This exhibition is a program of ExhibitsUSA, a national division of Mid-America Arts Alliance and The National Endowment for the Arts.

Image credit: "Sara Terry, Goldfish for saleâ€¦" , Capljina, Bosnia, March 30, 2004; digital print on aluminum, 14 7/16 x 22 inches; Courtesy of the artist.

events.name: Huskie Trek Talks 2026 - Proposal Deadline
events.description:
Huskie Trek Talks is coming back on Saturday, April 18, 2026, with another exciting opportunity for faculty and staff to showcase innovative research, impactful programs and novel initiatives. 

This unique experience elevates the hard work of our faculty and staff through storytelling. The event helps bring our community together by shining a bright light on the innovative Huskie spirit. With $80,000 in grant funding available to be awarded, plus the opportunity to secure a graduate assistantship, Huskie Trek Talks offers presenters not only a platform to inspire and inform but also tangible resources to advance their ideas and impact. 

Like TED Talks, Huskie Trek Talks feature concise, powerful stories from NIU faculty and staff who are shaping our university as innovators, educators, and leaders. The program not only showcases those selected to present but also helps prepare all participants for meaningful conversations with alumni and donors, extending the impact well beyond the stage. 

The deadline for proposal submission has been extended to Monday, Dec. 1.  Finalists will be chosen and notified in December. Presenter coaching will take place from January through early April in preparation for the Trek Talks event later that month. Submit your proposal today!

events.name: Breakthrough Community Business Academy
events.description:
The Breakthrough CBA is designed to cover all the essential topics you need to know about running a business, such as budgeting, marketing, bookkeeping, cash flow analyses, pricing strategies, and credit building. You'll also get to put new skills to the test in three small business simulation classes, where you'll compete with other teams and learn even more about marketing and finance.

WHY

We believe that communities and individuals have a vision for a thriving future and the journey to realize that future needs breakthrough moments and companionship.

WHAT

A 12-week, cohort-based academy for new and aspiring entrepreneurs, as well as early-stage businesses to cultivate community and build foundational business skills.

HOW

We develop relationships, learning opportunities, and community partnerships that move people from where they are to where they want to be for themselves, their families and their communities.

events.name: Legacies on Display: The Forbidden and Venerated Arts of Burma
events.description:
Through a display of nineteenth to twenty-first century Burmese ivory, silver, textiles and paintings, Legacies on Display reveals the complicated history of cultural and artistic objects and the lasting impact, intended or unintended, they leave behind as they travel from their point of origin to their final home in a museum, where a new history of public display and interpretation begins. Using the Burma Art Collection at NIU to explore these issues, this exhibition examines and questions the changing narratives that objects undergo as their life extends beyond a generation. From the once venerated elephant ivory carvings to the once forbidden modern protest paintings, Legacies on Display interrogates how meanings and interpretations are created, changed and left behind as part of our human record.

Standard museum opening hours are:
10 a.m. - 1 p.m. Wednesday
Noon - 6 p.m. Thursday, Friday
Noon - 3 p.m. Saturday

For more details visit niu.edu/artmuseum

events.name: Community College Leadership Program Information Session
events.description: Learn more about our Ed.D. in Higher Education with a specialization in Community College Leadership program. This 54-credit-hour cohort program focuses on developing the next generation of leaders in the community college environment and is centered around an innovative, practice-based, problem-solving approach to knowledge development and research. Online during the academic year with a 1-week in-person residency at our Naperville campus, this program is designed for the working professional. A focus on social justice, equity and inclusion are foundational elements infused across our curriculum, which helps prepare you to serve the increasingly diverse community college student population. To learn more about the program, join us for a virtual information session.

events.name: NIU Innovation Challenge
events.description:
High School and Community College Educators: Register Your Team for the NIU Innovation Challenge!

NIU STEAM and the Northern Illinois Center for Community Sustainability (NICCS) are excited to announce our upcoming Innovation Challenge for the 25-26 school year.

**

Learn more! Two free educator info sessions will be held online on Sept 23 and Oct 14 at 4 p.m.
https://calendar.niu.edu/event/niu-innovation-challenge-educator-info-sessions

**

About the NIU Innovation Challenge

Our goal is to provide a comprehensive opportunity for high school and community college students to strengthen their critical thinking and communication skills by collaborating with team members to solve an authentic problem. Please see the information below and check out one of our virtual information sessions to learn more about this event. We hope to see you there!

Students will work in teams of 2 to 4 to analyze an authentic problem and collaborate with an industry partner to generate a solution. By aligning to these goals, the Innovation Challenge meets the criteria established by ISBE for team-based challenges.

The challenge takes place in several stages:

Teams register and the challenge problem is release beginning on Sept. 23.In October, curricular resources and coach/sponsor support will be available.Teams are assigned a mentor to provide feedback on their written proposal.Through Dec. 5 teams work on their written solution with guidance from their educator and mentor.The top high school and community college teams advance to the final, in-person challenge on Saturday, Feb. 28, at Northern Illinois University. 

Learn more and register your student team at:

https://niusteam.niu.edu/innovation-challenge/

events.name: Youth Mental Health First Aid Virtual Training
events.description:
Youth Mental Health First Aid is a program designed to equip adults with the knowledge and skills needed to provide support to youth experiencing mental health challenges. This training spans a duration of 8 hours  through in-person sessions. In these sessions, participants will receive comprehensive training to learn how to identify early signs of mental health issues, offer immediate assistance, and guide young individuals toward appropriate professional help. The training provides participants with the Mental Health First Aid Action Plan: ALGEE. This plan provides guidance on how to interact with & help a child or adolescent who may be struggling with a mental health challenge or crisis. This program fosters understanding, reduces stigma, and promotes early intervention. Youth Mental Health First Aid Training creates a supportive community environment where participants are educated and able to effectively assist youth and become advocates for youth mental health, making a positive and lasting impact on the well-being of our youth. 

Maximum of 30 people can participate in each workshop 

Workshop is FREE!

events.name: Celebration Chorale Christmas Cantata
events.description:
Celebration Chorale Christmas Cantata

The Celebration Chorale announces its upcoming annual Christmas cantata, â€œSing We All Noelâ€ which will be presented at 7:00 p.m. Saturday, December 6th and Sunday, December 7th at 2:00 p.m. The production will be held at First United Methodist Church, 2501 North Annie Glidden Road in DeKalb.

â€œSing We All Noelâ€ is a dynamic collection of favorite carols and classics for choir and congregation.  The Celebration Chorale is under the direction of Christine Monteiro.

Although the Celebration Chorale practices and performs at FUMC in DeKalb, the musicians come from all over the area and include professionals and amateurs, longtime Chorale members, and those who are new to the group. The Chorale has singers representing over nine different church denominations and 10 local communities. 

There is no charge for the performances at the church, but a free-will offering will be taken. The church is an accessible facility. Parking is available adjacent to the church building.

For information about the concerts, or for information on joining the Celebration Chorale, email thecelebrationchorale@gmail.com; call Sally Mullis, Celebration Chorale Leadership Team President at (815) 739-6087 or visit their Facebook page at The Celebration Chorale.

events.description:
Jazz in Progress will partner with Chapter DX of Philanthropic Educational Organization International to hold its third annual Christmas concert. The free concert will begin at 7:00 p.m. Saturday, December 6th at Sycamore United Methodist Church, 160 Johnson Avenue.

The band will perform Christmas songs in a big band and modern jazz-style music format. Attendees are encouraged to donate nonperishable food items and free will offerings to the Sycamore Food Pantry.

Nonprofit Jazz in Progress raises funds for local community music programs, including the DeKalb, Sycamore, Genoa-Kingston, Hinckley-Big Rock, Indian Creek, Sandwich, Somonauk, Earlville and Leland school districts, St. Maryâ€™s School in DeKalb and the DeKalb County Community Foundation. 

P.E.O. Internationalâ€™s chapter is an education organization that motivates woman to achieve high education and celebrates womenâ€™s advancement through scholarships, grants, awards, loans and stewardship.

For information, visit facebook.com/JazzInProgress or peointernational.org

events.description:
Join us every second Tuesday from 4 p.m. to 5 p.m. in Founders Memorial Library to sip tea, work on yarn crafts, eat cookies, and discuss research and writing. The Scholarly Stitch Circle is more than just a knitting group; it's a community-building endeavor, fostering connections within the NIU community.

Experience anxiety reduction in this informal setting, where the dual focus on crafting and conversation alleviates the stress associated with scholarship. Embrace interdisciplinary collaboration as you knit your way to innovative research partnerships. As a bonus, discover and reinforce valuable research and writing support services available at the University Libraries and the University Writing Center. Join us in weaving a tapestry of creativity, camaraderie, and scholarly exploration!

In the Library's Lower Level Staff Lounge, behind Einstein's. All are welcome. Some supplies will be available, along with tea and cookies. No experience is necessary. While this is not a "how to" knit or crochet workshop, there may be participants able to help if you're a novice.

events.name: Do We Need a Plan? Selecting the Right Plan and What to Expect from the Process
events.description:
Civic Leadership Academy Online Course

Do We Need a Plan? Selecting the Right Plan and What to Expect from the Process

February 19, 2026  9-11:30 a.m.

An online webinar presented by Mim Evans., MS, Senior Research Associate, Center for Governmental Studies, Northern Illinois University.

Description: Sometimes communities find themselves faced with a pressing issue or an intriguing opportunity that they are not quite prepared to address. Or perhaps the general direction of the communityâ€™s future has become a topic of discussion. In these moments, the call for â€œa planâ€ emerges, no matter the communityâ€™s size, location or length of time since the last plan. Plans are an energizing process. They provide forums to exchange ideas and set future direction and priorities. But what kind of plan? Deciding whether a formal plan is necessary and, if so, what kind of plan it should be, can be challenging.


This class will present an overview of different kinds of plans often considered by local governments with the goal of aiding local staff and officials in deciding what plan to pursue. Additionally, what to expect from the planning process will be discussed. Examples of completed plans and statutory requirements will be presented. Types of plans covered will include comprehensive plans, strategic plans, economic development strategies, age-friendly plans, housing studies, and master plans focused on specific topics such as the arts, parks, or downtown.

Objectives:

 Addresses ICMA Practice Areas

events.name: Advice for International Students Struggling in Their Job Search
events.description:
International masterâ€™s students often face a range of challenges that can impact their ability to land a job and remain in the United States. Additionally, students today are navigating economic and political uncertainty that can affect both their job search and immigration status. So, what can international students do to succeed in this highly competitive and uncertain job market? In this webinar, youâ€™ll learn the components of a successful job search in North America. Weâ€™ll discuss what hiring managers look for in a competitive market and how to maximize your chances of landing a job or internship after graduation. While there are many factors beyond our control, weâ€™ll discuss what international students CAN do to prepare for the future. Join Beyond Graduate School for this webinar designed for masterâ€™s students from all academic disciplines who are wondering:

Â· What factors do I need to consider as an international student job searching in the US?

Â· What can I do to improve my chances of landing a job in the US?

events.name: Midwest Sport and Exercise Psychology Symposium (MSEPS)
events.description:
The AASP Midwest Sport and Exercise Psychology Symposium (MSEPS) is a student-led, student-focused conference designed for individuals interested in, or actively pursuing, careers in sport, exercise, and performance psychology. 

MSEPS offers a distinctive experience centered on programming that supports the educational and professional development of undergraduate and graduate students. Attendees benefit from opportunities to network, gain mentorship, engage in meaningful dialogue, and receive feedback on ongoing research. Representing dozens of institutions across the Midwest states, the symposium reflects a strong regional commitment to advancing the next generation of sport and exercise psychology professionals. 

For information related to abstract submission, lodging and registration, please visit our MSEPS website. We look forward to welcoming you to Northern Illinois University in March!

events.description:
It's Jazz Combo Day! Join us for a day designed to bring individual jazz high school players to collaborate with other area high school students, NIU Jazz faculty, and guest artists.

This program requires an audition or invitation to participate. Complete our audition form by Feb. 25, 2026. If accepted, you will participate in one of several combos at the event. Jazz Combo Day includes workshops, rehearsals, dinner, and performances from the day's student combos and of course, our NIU Jazz faculty.  

Check-in begins at 8 a.m. in the School of Music Concert Hall Lobby. Lunch is on your own. Dinner is included with your registration fee.

There is a $75 event registration fee that includes dinner for the participant. Guests may attend the performance for free, but if they would like to join the participant for dinner, there is a $25 fee per guest meal. A link to payment will be sent in the confirmation email. 

Scholarship recipients will still need to complete the payment form. You will indicate you are receiving a scholarship and also have the option to purchase additional dinner tickets.

Registration deadline is March 4. Cancellation refunds are available up to five business days prior to the event. Contact Kristin Sherman at ksherman2@niu.edu or 815-753-1450 with questions.

events.name: Huskie Trek Talks 2026: Ideas in Motion
events.description:
Huskie Trek Talks is coming back on Saturday, April 18, 2026, with another exciting opportunity for faculty and staff to showcase innovative research, impactful programs and novel initiatives. 

This unique experience elevates the hard work of our faculty and staff through storytelling. The event helps bring our community together by shining a bright light on the innovative Huskie spirit. With $80,000 in grant funding available to be awarded, plus the opportunity to secure a graduate assistantship, Huskie Trek Talks offers presenters not only a platform to inspire and inform but also tangible resources to advance their ideas and impact. 

Like TED Talks, Huskie Trek Talks feature concise, powerful stories from NIU faculty and staff who are shaping our university as innovators, educators, and leaders. The program not only showcases those selected to present but also helps prepare all participants for meaningful conversations with alumni and donors, extending the impact well beyond the stage.

events.name: International Guitar Recital Series featuring Gaelle Solal
events.description:
GaÃ«lle Solal is a renowned classical guitarist from Marseille, France. She is known for her passionate and virtuosic playing style and has garnered numerous awards throughout her career, including the 1st Grand Prix at the Michele Pittaluga International Classical Guitar Competition, and the 2nd Prize at the prestigious Guitar Foundation of America Competition. She began playing guitar at the age of six and went on to study at the Conservatoire de Paris and the Hochschule fÃ¼r Musik und Tanz KÃ¶ln. 

Beyond her classical roots, Solal has explored various musical styles, including Brazilian, jazz, and world music. She has also collaborated with artists from other disciplines like contemporary dance, tap dancing, mime, and clowning, creating unique and engaging performances. A strong advocate for female representation in the guitar world, she is the founder of the "Guitar'Elles" association. 

Solal has performed extensively across the globe, captivating audiences in over 35 countries at renowned venues and festivals. She has also premiered new works by contemporary composers, according to Guitars International. In addition to her performance career, Solal has also shared her expertise through teaching positions at conservatories in Spain and by giving masterclasses internationally.
